name: 2-(trifluoromethyl)acrylic acid
Reason: 2-(trifluoromethyl)acrylic acid has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The trifluoromethyl group introduces a significant dipole moment, which can increase the melting point due to stronger intermolecular interactions. Each trifluoromethyl group can be estimated to add approximately +20°C to the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and rigidity. Additionally, the carbonyl group can participate in hydrogen bonding, which may contribute to a slight increase in the melting point.
